conceptual.question: Explain what happens to reaction velocity as substrate concentration increases from much less than Km to much greater than Km.
hints: Consider the MM equation at extreme [S] values

solution.summary: Velocity transitions from first-order (linear with [S]) to zero-order (independent of [S]).
solution.detailed: At [S] << Km: V ≈ (Vmax/Km)[S], linear increase. At [S] >> Km: V ≈ Vmax, constant (enzyme saturated). The Km marks the transition point, where V = Vmax/2.

computational.question: An enzyme has Vmax = 100 μmol/min and Km = 5 mM. What is V when [S] = 15 mM?
What [S] is needed to achieve 90% of Vmax?

applied.question: A drug inhibitor increases apparent Km from 5 mM to 15 mM without changing Vmax. What type of inhibition is this?
hints: What parameters change with each inhibitor type?

solution.detailed: Competitive inhibitors increase apparent Km (reduce apparent affinity) but don't affect Vmax (can be overcome at high [S]). This pattern—Km increases, Vmax unchanged—is diagnostic of competitive inhibition.

challenge.question: The Lineweaver-Burk equation is 1/V = (Km/Vmax)(1/[S]) + 1/Vmax. If the y-intercept is 0.02 and slope is 0.1, what are Vmax and Km?

solution.detailed: y-intercept = 1/Vmax = 0.02, so Vmax = 50. Slope = Km/Vmax = 0.1, so Km = 0.1 × 50 = 5.
